dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, should Twitter or Facebook, um, just let politicians say anything in their ads? Even if it's, you know, not totally true?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, should Twitter or Facebook, um, just let politicians say anything in their ads? Even if it's, you know, not totally true?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's, that's a huge question, A. And it's exactly what Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey have been, like, publicly duking it out over.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's, that's a huge question, A. And it's exactly what Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey have been, like, publicly duking it out over.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now the two billionaire tech founders are at odds over how to handle free speech and political advertising, defending opposite views of a heavily debated internet issue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, they're fighting? I thought they were, um, both just tech bros. What's the beef?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, they're fighting? I thought they were, um, both just tech bros. What's the beef?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Jack Dorsey, over at Twitter, he just outright banned political advertising. Said reach should be earned, not bought.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Jack Dorsey, over at Twitter, he just outright banned political advertising. Said reach should be earned, not bought.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Twitter announced on Wednesday its intent to abolish political advertising on its platform, saying that political message reach should be earned, not bought.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. So no more, uh, buying influence? That's kinda big, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. So no more, uh, buying influence? That's kinda big, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it was a direct shot, obviously, at Zuckerberg, who, um, defends Facebook's policy of letting politicians run ads, even with, like, deceptive statements.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it was a direct shot, obviously, at Zuckerberg, who, um, defends Facebook's policy of letting politicians run ads, even with, like, deceptive statements.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dorseys comments took aim at how Zuckerberg has defended Facebooks political ads policy, which allows politicians and political candidates to make false claims in advertisements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But, like, why? What's Zuckerberg's argument? Free speech or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, like, why? What's Zuckerberg's argument? Free speech or something?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. He sees Facebook as a platform for free expression, you know, letting users post thoughts unless they incite violence. He even gave this big speech at Georgetown.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. He sees Facebook as a platform for free expression, you know, letting users post thoughts unless they incite violence. He even gave this big speech at Georgetown.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zuckerberg has positioned Facebook as an American-values-based company that champions free speech by allowing anyone to publish any of their thoughts, as long as they dont threaten physical harm. ... Zuckerberg said during a Georgetown University speech earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And Dorsey's response was, like, what? Agitated?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Dorsey's response was, like, what? Agitated?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. Dorsey, uh, tweeted that it's not just about free expression, it's about paying for reach, which has, um, dire consequences for democracy. He even used a winking emoji!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally. Dorsey, uh, tweeted that it's not just about free expression, it's about paying for reach, which has, um, dire consequences for democracy. He even used a winking emoji!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This isnt about free expression, Dorsey said in a series of tweets. This is about paying for reach. And paying to increase the reach of political speech has significant ramifications that todays democratic infrastructure may not be prepared to handle. ... Then, he added a wink.

dialogue_turns.text: A winking emoji? That's kinda passive-aggressive. So this isn't just about ads, is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A winking emoji? That's kinda passive-aggressive. So this isn't just about ads, is it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, it’s deeper. Dorsey even called Zuckerberg's free speech argument "fundamentally flawed and misleading" at a summit. Said he was, like, creatively rewriting the truth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's deeper. Dorsey even called Zuckerberg's free speech argument fundamentally flawed and misleading at a summit. Said he was, like, creatively rewriting the truth.

There's some amount of revisionist history in all his storytelling, Dorsey said of Zuckerberg.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, um, what about that Libra project? I heard Dorsey hated it.

dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, when asked about joining Libra, Dorsey's response was, Hell, no, it's a disaster. Pretty clear, huh?

dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So what did Zuck say back, or, um, did he just let it go?

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, no, Zuck hit back hard. He said Twitter was "struggling" and Facebook was "thriving." Claimed Facebook's safety investment, like, surpassed Twitter's entire annual revenue.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its why Twitter cant do as good of a job as we can, Zuckerberg said. I mean, they face, qualitatively, the same types of issues. But they cant put in the investment. Our investment on safety is bigger than the whole revenue of their company.
